task.title: Advantages of using DITA for policy and procedure documents
task.shortdesc: Many companies have a vast number of their documents, many of which have significantly overlapping concepts. Efforts to write a policy or procedure the traditional way can be thwarted by questions like “where does this information really belong?” It’s a question that just goes away when you can reassemble a document using a disposable map, then assemble another manual later using some of the same bits.

section.p: Localisation and translation isn’t at all of interest in engineering, nor really is the whole genre of product information, which is where DITA’s core support seems to reside
Many companies have a vast number of their documents, many of which have significantly overlapping concepts.

Specific systems can fundamentally cut across disciplines (track, signals, etc.) It would be a simple (very big, but simple) exercise to cut the material up and reassemble it cleanly into manuals using DITA.

Efforts to write a manual the traditional way can be thwarted by questions like “where does this information really belong?” It’s a question that just goes away when you can reassemble a document using a disposable map, then assemble another manual later using some of the same bits.

I personally suspect that there a vast underworld of unmaintained policy and procedure documents in lots of big companies and government organisations that I know DITA could make a real difference with.
